body_text.text: Forgetting 'routine' DVT and stroke during COVID-19 is a parallel pandemic that will be costly if ignored BSc (Hons) Dear Editor, 1 2

The current COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in a huge strategic and clinical change within the UK 3 National Health Service (NHS) to ensure it can cope with the surge in demand of respiratory 4 patients. However, when attention is acutely shifted, routine care will suffer and that could be 5 deadly for some, and enormously expensive for the NHS in the long-term. Figure Figure 1B highlights a similar  19 decrease to that we have seen in DVT referrals for Duplex. Venous duplex referrals are a surrogate 20 for the number of patients accessing primary or secondary care for DVT. Therefore, the decline 21 seen may not be due to administration or medical abandonment but perhaps due to cultural 22 avoidance of health care as a result of COVID-19 fear. 23

Since the UK went into lockdown on 23 rd March 2019, six acute 13 NHS trusts performed on average (mean ± standard deviation) 27±12 Duplex scans for Deep 14 Venous Thrombosis (DVT), where 21% were positive. This is compared to the exact same week in 15 2019 where 70±35 scans were performed; 20% which were positive for DVT. This represents a 16 61% drop in DVT assessment and up to 59% of potential DVT's that have not been identified. 1B shows the decline in interest over time of public searches using search terms of DVT in 18 the Google Trends® health category in the United Kingdom.
